text: Sleep under an insecticide-treated bed net every night. Check for holes and tuck it properly.
Pregnant women and children under 5 are at higher risk — ensure consistent net use and seek prompt testing for fever.
Reduce mosquito breeding: clear gutters, cover water containers, and remove stagnant water around the home.
Drink and use safe water only: boil, treat, or use bottled water for drinking, brushing teeth, and washing fruits/veggies.
Wash hands with soap and safe water: after using the toilet and before preparing/eating food.
During outbreaks, avoid raw or undercooked foods; eat food that is steaming hot or peel fruits yourself.
If you have watery diarrhoea, start Oral Rehydration Solution (ORS) immediately and seek care — dehydration can be deadly.
Follow Nigeria CDC advisories during rainy season and outbreaks (e.g., Lagos 2024) and report symptoms early.
Wash hands before and after changing pads/tampons. Change pads every 4–6 hours (up to 8h depending on flow).
Dispose used pads safely: wrap securely and place in a bin. Do not flush.
Choose products that suit you (disposable pads, reusable pads, cups). Keep reusable materials clean and fully dry before reuse.
Keep immunizations up to date and use insecticide-treated nets for children under 5.
For diarrhoea, encourage fluids and give WHO low-osmolarity ORS; watch for danger signs like lethargy or no urine.
Breastfeed infants exclusively for the first 6 months; introduce safe complementary foods thereafter.
Stay up to date with vaccination and local guidance. Avoid crowded, poorly ventilated spaces.
Wear a well-fitted mask when distancing is not possible or ventilation is poor; keep hands clean.
Seek testing within 24 hours of fever in malaria areas; avoid self-medication without diagnosis.
Oral cholera vaccines (OCV) can help in areas with active transmission; follow public health guidance.
Track your cycle to anticipate supplies, manage symptoms, and seek care if periods are extremely painful or very heavy.
If a child shows signs of severe dehydration (very sleepy, sunken eyes, no urine), go to a health facility immediately.
